Article.ArticleTitle: ABT-199 (Venetoclax), a BH3-mimetic Bcl-2 inhibitor, does not cause Ca2+ -signalling dysregulation or toxicity in pancreatic acinar cells.

Abstract.AbstractText: Many cancer cells depend on anti-apoptotic B cell lymphoma 2 (Bcl-2) proteins for their survival. Bcl-2 antagonism through BH3 mimetics emerged as novel anti-cancer therapy. ABT-199 (Venetoclax), a recently developed BH3 mimetic inhibiting selectively Bcl-2, was introduced into the clinic for treatment of relapsed chronic lymphocytic leukaemia. Early generations of Bcl-2 inhibitors evoked sustained Ca2+ responses in pancreatic acinar cells (PACs) inducing cell death. Therefore, BH3 mimetics could potentially be toxic for the pancreas when used to treat cancer. Although ABT-199 was shown to kill Bcl-2-dependent cancer cells without affecting intracellular Ca2+ signalling, its effects on PACs have not yet been determined. Hence, it becomes essential and timely to assess whether the recently approved anti-leukaemic drug might have potentially pancreatotoxic effects.
Single-cell Ca2+ measurements and cell death analysis were performed on isolated mouse PACs.

We show that inhibition of Bcl-2 via ABT-199 neither elicited intracellular Ca2+ signalling on its own nor potentiated Ca2+ signalling induced by physiological/pathophysiological stimuli in PACs. Although ABT-199 did not affect cell death in PACs, using conditions that killed ABT-199 sensitive cancer cells, cytosolic Ca2+ extrusion was slightly enhanced in the presence of the drug. In contrast, inhibition of Bcl-XL potentiated pathophysiological Ca2+ responses in PACs, without exacerbating cell death.

Our results demonstrate that apart from having a modest effect on cytosolic Ca2+ extrusion, ABT-199 does not alter substantially intracellular Ca2+ homeostasis in normal PACs and should be safe for the pancreas during cancer treatment.
